item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: The impact of Covid-19 in Belgium
item.description:
The blog is a further research about COVID-19 in Belgium in economic aspect. According to Johns Hopkins University Center for System Science and Engineering invention provided latest version of the data, in the first 180 days Belgium reported death number took a small place in the European Union, however, Belgium took the highest death rate in the world which we found the result in the last blog. Figure 1 shows reported deaths number in 8 particular European countries in the first 180 days since the epidemic spread out. The graph shows the same trend were increased rapidly in the first 50 days.

Figure 1: Reported deaths number in European Union.

Thanks for lockdown policy in many countries that made the outbreak under control, in Figure 2 that the latest update in 16th Sep 2020, reported deaths number in European mostly were under 100 cases. In Belgium, it seems that outbreak is under control that keep the number under 10 cases. For further research can have a look at tidycovid19

Figure 2: Covid19:Reported deaths(new cases per day)

Impact of Gross Domestic Product in Belgium

As it surveys an economy ravaged by the disease, Figure 3 which dataset was downloaded from Real Gross Domestic Product for Belgium shows that Belgium real gross domestic product (GDP) from first quarter of 2005 to first quarter of 2020. There are two apparent fluctuations that one was from 2008 to 2009 which meet economic crisis, another one was from late 2019 to recent which under COVID-19 outbreak. The horizon line can clearly clarify that first quarter of 2020, GDP for Belgium fell to same level of 2019 which just went through an economic crisis.

Figure 3: Real GDP in Belgium

Comparison GDP between Euro Aera and Belgium

For a better understanding what impact that virus bring to, I found 19 countries in European aera of their total GDP resources from Gross Domestic Product for Euro area (19 countries). Figure 4 compared to total GDP of 19 countries in European area, Belgium’s GDP have a same moving trend as European countries. However, in the last two quarter that Belgium has wider variations than normal.

Figure 4: GDP comparison between Belgium and European Union(19 countries)

Impact of Unemployment Rate in Belgium

Meanwhile, Belgium limps back to work after the outbreak, citizens job prospects are truly bleak. It was a period that the workforce as prospective employers mull lay-offs of hiring freezes. For a middle class used to relentlessly strong economic growth, the stock will be great. Figure 5 illustrated unemployment rate from first quarter of 2015 to first quarter of 2020, it seems that there was a tendency to decrease unemployment rate since 2015 before epidemic happened. The latest data showed that unemployment rate in Belgium has obvious rose in first quarter in 2020.

Figure 5: Unemployment Rate in Belgium

Comparison Unemployment Rate between Euro Area and Belgium

Comparing unemployment rate around European area, Belgium unemployment rate was higher than average from the past five year but all with a bright future that unemployment rate fell year by year even Figure 6 shown the gap between Belgium and average European area was increasingly getting bigger. With an unexpected epidemic that every thing seems changed that both have a same turning point since 2020, the tide of unemployment was coming fast and furious and we don’t know how long will this cold wave last. If you have interest for impact in economy, I would like to recommend you to visit Alfred which recorded variance of economy historial data.

Figure 6: Comparison of Unemployment Rate between Belgium and Euro area

There is no doubt that virus has hit every country hard and it is a big question that we don’t know how bad will COVID-19 be for the economy around the world. There are so many bad news in 2020 and hopefully we can get COVID-19 vaccine soon and pull through together.

Reference

Kun Ren and Kenton Russell (2019). formattable: Create ‘Formattable’ Data Structures.https://renkun.me/formattable,

Allaire, J, Y Xie, J McPherson, J Luraschi, K Ushey, A Atkins, H Wickham, J Cheng, W Chang, and R Iannone (2020). rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. R package version 2.1. https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

Grolemund, G and H Wickham (2011). Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate. Journal of Statistical Software 40(3), 1–25.

Wickham, H, M Averick, J Bryan, W Chang, LD McGowan, R François, G Grolemund, A Hayes, L Henry, J Hester, M Kuhn, TL Pedersen, E Miller, SM Bache, K Müller, J Ooms, D Robinson, DP Seidel, V Spinu, K Takahashi, D Vaughan, C Wilke, K Woo, and H Yutani (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software 4(43), 1686.

Joachim Gassen (2020). tidycovid19: Download, Tidy and Visualize Covid-19 Related Data. R package version 0.0.0.9000.

Steve Miller (2020). stevemisc: Miscellaneous Functions/Data That Only Steve Finds Useful. R package version 0.1.17.

Xie, Y (2020a). bookdown: Authoring Books and Technical Documents with R Markdown. R package version 0.18. https://github.com/rstudio/bookdown

Onno Kleen (2020). alfred: Downloading Time Series from ALFRED Database for Various Vintages. R package version 0.1.8. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=alfred

item.title: Coronavirus in Belgium
item.description:
The blog is a research about coronavirus(COVID-19) in Belgium from March 2020 to August 2020 and used the data source from Kaggle and used the dataset from package coronavirus.

You can visualise the number of COVID-19 cased confirmed in Belgium from March to August 2020 in Figure 1. It shows that April was the most seriousness month that have the largest infected population. Since then, people started pay attention and took anti-epidemic action and the confirmed cases got a good result. However, there are still have high number of confirmed cases.

Figure 1: Cases confrimed in Belgium since March 2020

For further research, it found that the elder got higher infected rate, the table show below listed confirmed cases in difference provinces and regions and difference age group. It shows that the largest number were from 80-89 age group in every region in April.

Variables MONTH REGION PROVINCE AGEGROUP NUMBER
1 4 Flanders WestVlaanderen 80-89 63
2 4 Brussels Brussels 80-89 62
3 4 Flanders Antwerpen 80-89 62
4 4 Flanders WestVlaanderen 50-59 62
5 4 Flanders OostVlaanderen 50-59 60
6 4 Flanders OostVlaanderen 80-89 60
7 4 Wallonia Hainaut 70-79 60
8 4 Wallonia Hainaut 80-89 60
9 4 Brussels Brussels 70-79 59
10 4 Flanders Antwerpen 50-59 59

We found that not only did the elder would easier infected, but also got a higher death rate. Figure 2 shown below that number of mortality in three regions in Belgium, all the age group people in the lists and especially in the elder group. Brussels is the least number of mortality among the data set.

Figure 2: Mortaity numbers from March to August in three reigions

Compare with United State and China which are the country got serious epidemic, we calculate the death rate and recovery rate. The interactive table shows below that Belgium got the second highest death rate in April. During this research, I found an article online said that Belgium got the highest death rate around the world. What made Belgium rank the first place? If you interested about it, you can spend few minutes to have a look Is Belgium the world’s deadliest COVID-19 country or just the most honest?

Belgium is a beautiful country, it is famous for its chocolate and it has plenty of historical treasures. Hope the epidemic will end soon and I will have the opportunity to travel.

Reference

Allaire, J, Y Xie, J McPherson, J Luraschi, K Ushey, A Atkins, H Wickham, J Cheng, W Chang, and R Iannone (2020). rmarkdown: Dynamic Documents for R. R package version 2.1. https://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.

Grolemund, G and H Wickham (2011). Dates and Times Made Easy with lubridate. Journal of Statistical Software 40(3), 1–25.

Wickham, H, M Averick, J Bryan, W Chang, LD McGowan, R François, G Grolemund, A Hayes, L Henry, J Hester, M Kuhn, TL Pedersen, E Miller, SM Bache, K Müller, J Ooms, D Robinson, DP Seidel, V Spinu, K Takahashi, D Vaughan, C Wilke, K Woo, and H Yutani (2019). Welcome to the tidyverse. Journal of Open Source Software 4(43), 1686.

Xie, Y (2020a). bookdown: Authoring Books and Technical Documents with R Markdown. R package version 0.18. https://github.com/rstudio/bookdown

Kirill Müller and Hadley Wickham (2020). tibble: Simple Data Frames. R package version 3.0.3. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=tibble

Dean Attali and Almende B.V. (2019). timevis:Create Interactive Timeline Visualizations in R. R package version 0.5. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=timevis

David Robinson, Alex Hayes and Simon Couch(2020). broom: Convert Statistical Objects into Tidy Tibbles. R package version 0.7.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=broom

Achim Zeileis and Gabor Grothendieck (2005). zoo: S3 Infrastructure for Regular and Irregular Time Series. Journal of Statistical Software, 14(6), 1-27. doi:10.18637/jss.v014.i06

Rami Krispin and Jarrett Byrnes (2020). coronavirus: The 2019 Novel Coronavirus COVID-19 (2019-nCoV) Dataset. R package version 0.3.0. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=coronavirus

Bhaskar Karambelkar (2017). widgetframe: ‘Htmlwidgets’ in Responsive ‘iframes’. R package version 0.3.1. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=widgetframe

Kun Ren and Kenton Russell (2019). formattable: Create ‘Formattable’ Data Structures.https://renkun.me/formattable,

Evgeniya K (2020). COVID-19 in Belgium. https://www.kaggle.com/evgeniako/covid19-in-belgium

Yihui Xie, Joe Cheng and Xianying Tan (2020). DT: A Wrapper of the JavaScript Library ‘DataTables’. R package version 0.15. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=DT

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example journal article
item.description:
Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
